description: Easy - The Gallic Invasion and Recovery

questions.question: Who were the Gauls, and where did they originally come from?
options: Germanic peoples from lands east of the Rhine River
Indo-European Celtic peoples from Central Europe and the Danube region
Greek colonists who had expanded northward into Mediterranean regions
Etruscan warriors who migrated from what is now Tuscany
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Gauls - Who Were They

questions.question: In what year did the Gallic army under Brennus invade Rome?
options: 410 BCE
400 BCE
390 BCE
370 BCE
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Specific Invasion - Brennus and His Army

questions.question: What was the name of the river where Roman forces were defeated by the Gauls?
options: The Tiber River near Rome's city center
The Arno River in northern Italy where Rome's allies lived
The Po River in Cisalpine Gaul where Gauls originally settled
The Allia River, a tributary of the Tiber about 11 miles north of Rome
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Invasion and Battle of the Allia

questions.question: How did Gallic warriors fight, and why were they so dangerous to Romans?
options: They used crossbows from long distances and avoided hand-to-hand combat
They were large, strong fighters who relied on abandon and ferocity with long swords
They wore heavy armor and fought in tight formations like Roman soldiers
They used poisoned weapons and fought primarily at night to surprise enemies

questions.question: Who was the patrician general credited with expelling the Gauls and rebuilding Rome?
options: Camillus
Brennus
Licinius
Sextius

questions.question: What was the most direct consequence of the Gallic invasion on Roman military organization?
options: Rome decided never to fight foreign wars again and focused only on internal peace
Rome hired Gallic mercenaries to replace soldiers who had died in battle
Rome eliminated the consular system and created a permanent military dictatorship
Rome had to rebuild its army and improve military organization after catastrophic defeat
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Impact on Roman Society

questions.question: How did the Gallic invasion affect the Conflict of the Orders between patricians and plebeians?
options: It completely ended the conflict and made patricians and plebeians permanent equals
Patricians and plebeians had to work together temporarily to defend Rome and expel the Gauls
It caused plebeians to abandon their demands for political power and accept patrician rule
It gave patricians enough power to permanently crush plebeian political aspirations
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Impact on Roman Society

questions.question: What specific advantage did Gallic peoples possess that made conquest possible for them?
options: They had superior numbers compared to all Mediterranean peoples
They possessed superior iron-working technology and better weapons than many peoples
They had developed naval power that no one else in the Mediterranean could match
They used magic and supernatural powers that made them invincible in battle
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Why the Gauls? Celtic Advantages

questions.question: What was Cisalpine Gaul?
options: A Gallic kingdom in southern Italy that traded with Rome
Gaul on the far side of the Alps where Celtic peoples originated
Gaul on this side of the Alps where Celtic tribes settled in the Po River valley
A Roman colony established north of the Tiber River by patrician generals

questions.question: According to the sources, how long did the Gallic occupation of Rome last?
options: Several months before the Gauls withdrew or were expelled
A few weeks before they were immediately expelled
Several years of continuous occupation and Roman subjugation
The Gauls permanently settled Rome and became the new ruling class
